conclusion: To determine whether the difference in displacement between the two objects (A and B) necessarily continuously increases over time from t=0 to t=t1, we need to analyze the given velocity-time graph for both objects.
The displacement of an object can be found by calculating the area under the velocity-time graph.
For each time interval, the displacement d of an object can be calculated as: d = ∫ v(t) dt.

The difference in displacement Δd between the two objects A and B at any time t is given by the difference in their respective areas under the curve: Δd(t) = Area under the curve for A - Area under the curve for B.
Both objects have positive velocity throughout the entire time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
At t=0, both objects start from rest with zero initial velocity.
The graph shows that Object A reaches a higher peak velocity than Object B before t1.

premise: Both objects move in the same direction and Object A has a higher maximum velocity than Object B.
conclusion: Object A will cover more distance than Object B initially.

premise: Object A starts decelerating after reaching its peak, while Object B's velocity continues to increase until t1.
conclusion: Object A will begin to lose ground to Object B.

premise: Initially, due to Object A's higher velocity, Δd(t) will be positive, meaning Object A is ahead.
conclusion: The difference in position will decrease, and eventually, Object A will fall behind Object B.

premise: The difference in displacement between the two objects does not necessarily continuously increase over the entire time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
conclusion: No, the difference in displacement between the two objects does not necessarily continuously increase over the time interval from t=0 to t=t1.
